ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Timepoint/visit label
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2; Morning, At Bedtime

ElementDescription: Miscellaneous comments on study, interview, methodology relevant to this form data
Define ''team'' for the purpose of this questionnaire.
Membership on my team changes so frequently that we don't really have a team.
My team has the right mix of members, a group of people who bring different clinical perspectives and experiences to the work.
It is clear what is, and what is not, acceptable behavior on my team.
Our practice recognizes and reinforces teams that perform well.
My team has goals that are clear, useful, and appropriate to my practice.
There is a real desire among team members to work collaboratively.
If asked, I could explain every team member's role and how they overlap.
My team encourages patients to be active participants in decisions about their care.
My team does a good job of helping patients understand their care plan.
The patient's needs and preferences are treated as an essential part of my team's decisions.
Each team member shares accountability for team decisions and outcomes.
My team has developed effective strategies for sharing patient treatment goals among team members.
Relevant information about changes in patient status or care plan is reported to the appropriate team member in a timely manner.
All team members effectively use the patient health record as a communication tool.
My team addresses patients' concerns effectively through team meetings and discussions.
Team meetings provide an open, comfortable, safe place to discuss concerns.
When team members disagree, all points of view are considered before deciding on a solution.
My team has an effective process for conflict management.
Members of my team depend on each other for their special knowledge and expertise.
Overall, members of our team do a very good job of coordinating their different patient-related jobs and activities.
I regularly communicate with other members of my team.
Members of my team act upon the information I communicate to them.
Members of my team show respect for each other's roles and expertise.
Members of my team really trust each other's work and contributions related to patient care.
The way my team members interact makes the delivery of care highly efficient.
The way my team members interact is very good for the quality of patient care.
Working on a team like mine keeps members of my team enthusiastic and interested in their jobs.
I feel integral to my team.
I experience excellent teamwork with the members of my team.
Conditions for Team Effectiveness Score (Sum of 4 items: 1-rev,2,3,4)
Shared Understanding Score (Sum of 6 items: 5-10)
Process for Accountability Score (Sum of 1 item: 11)
Process for Communication of Information Exchange Score (Sum of 5 items: 12-16)
Process for Conflict Resolution Score (Sum of 2 items: 17,18)
Acting and Feeling like a Team Score (Sum of 6 items: 19-24)
Perceived Team Effectiveness Score (Sum of 5 items: 25-29)
